Pronunciation: t s A _ s i . u
Definition: Char siew is a popular Cantonese barbecue dish commonly found in Singapore and Malaysia. It consists of marinated strips of pork that are skewered and roasted until caramelized and slightly charred on the edges. The name "char siew" literally translates to "fork-roasted" in Cantonese.\n\nAlternate spellings for char siew may include "char siu". It is commonly served as a side dish with rice or noodles in hawker centers and restaurants across Singapore. Some variations of char siew may use pork belly instead of pork loin or have a sweeter glaze, depending on the cook or the region.
